awd_titl_txt: Fast and Stable Compact Exponential Time Difference Based Methods for Some Parabolic Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop and analyze fast, stable, and accurate methods for numerical solutions of a family of parabolic equations that appear in diverse applications in science and engineering. The research will lead to production of very efficient and effective computational tools for problems typified by phase transition modeling, chemical reactions, population dynamics, cell membrane modeling, molecular beam epitaxy, fluid dynamics, and light propagation. The well-designed robust high-order algorithms would allow researchers to accurately catch the dynamics of these systems without high computational costs. This project also offers new insights into the understanding of the kinetic processes of microstructure coarsening, shape transformation of membrane lipid vesicles, and epitaxial growth of thin films through extensive numerical simulations. Graduate students will be directly involved in and benefit from their participation in the frontier research.
 
Although exponential time integrator based techniques have been widely researched in the literature for solving semilinear or nonlinear parabolic equations of different orders, there still lack careful numerical and theoretical studies on accurate and stable treatments of stiff nonlinearities, direct and explicit incorporation of various inhomogeneous boundary conditions, and corresponding fast implementation algorithms. The methods in this project are explicit in nature, and they will utilize compact representations of high-order finite differences or spectral approximations for spatial operators in a rectangular domain, exponential multistep or Runge-Kutta approximations for accurate time integrations of boundary and stiff nonlinear terms, linear splitting schemes for effectively enhancing numerical stabilities, and FFT-based fast calculations for greatly reducing computational costs. The research will systematically study several techniques for improving accuracy and efficiency of the compact exponential time differencing methods in both space and time, and develop energy stability and error analyses for these schemes.  The project will also generalize and apply these methods to some important problems arising from the study of some biological and physical phenomena, such as phase field bending energy models for cell membrane shape transformation and molecular beam epitaxy models for thin film growth.

por.por_cntn:
Parabolic or evolution equations of different orders, either linear or nonlinear, are of broad interests as they can represent many mathematical models in diverse applications in science and engineering, thus the development, analysis and implementation of efficient and robust numerical algorithms for their solutions are very important in practice. The exponential integrator approach, such as the exponential time differencing (ETD) method, has been proven to a very effective technique for time discretizations of these types of problems with strong stiffness. On the other hand, there still lack careful numerical and theoretical studies of the ETD method on not only accurate but also stable treatments of the stiff terms, direct and explicit incorporation of various inhomogeneous boundary conditions, and scalable algorithms on modern massively distributed computer systems.

 

This project made some important contributions in advancing the exponential time differencing method and other effective time integration schemes: (1) developed and analyzed fast, accurate and stable ETD algorithms for applications problems across many fields, such as the classic and nonlocal Allen-Cahn and Cahn-Hilliard equations for phase separation and grain coarsening, the phase-field elastic bending energy model for vesicle membrane, the incompressible viscous flows, the epitaxial growth model without slope selection, and the unsteady and steady compressible fluid dynamics problems; (2) developed and tested the localized ETD methods based on overlapping domain decomposition, which are highly scalable and thus suitable for large-scale parallel computations; and (3) developed and analyzed energy-stable linear schemes for time stepping of the diffuse interface model with Peng-Robinson equation of state, the binary fluid-surfactant phase field model, and the time-dependent nonlocal diffusion problems. In particular, It is worth noting that the PI and his collaborators developed and implemented the compact localized ETD method for extreme-scale parallel phase field simulations of three-dimensional coarsening dynamics on the Sunway ``TaihuLight'' supercomputer. This work won one of the finalists in the supercomputing's most prestigious competition, 2016 ACM Gordon Bell Prize in high-performance computing. It demonstrates that the latest advent of high-performance computing platform and the new advances in algorithm design are now offering us the possibility to simulate the coarsening dynamics accurately for studying important properties of materials at unprecedented spatial and time scales.

 

Two Ph.D. students were partially supported as Graduate Research Assistants by the project over its three-year period, and they received trainings and performed researches in numerical analysis and scientific computing with a focus on algorithms and simulations for phase field models in materials science and petroleum engineering and for turbulent flow problems. Fifteen papers have been published in leading academic journals and conference proceedings, and about forty-one seminar/colloquium talks and fifteen conference/workshop presentations have been delivered, to disseminate the research findings of the project to the public.
